msItem.title: Compleynt of Mars
msItem.incipit:
GLadeth ye lovers on the morowe gray
Loo Venus rysen amonge yow rowes rede…
msItem.explicit:
…that neuer did but gentilesse
kytheth therfor on her summe kyndenesse

msItem.title: Complaint of Venus
msItem.rubric: The compleynt of Venus (scribal, in margin beside first line, f. 19); Complaynt of Mars and Venus (f. 15);
msItem.incipit:
Ther nys so high comfort to my plesaunce
When that I am in eny heuynesse…
msItem.explicit:
…To folowe worde by worde the curiosite
of graunson floure of hem that maken in fraunce

msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the complaynt of venus and Mars (f. 20v)

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Complaint of the Black Knight
msItem.incipit:
In May when fflora the fressh lusty quene
the soyle hath clad in grene rede and white…
msItem.explicit:
…exiled be that I may not ateyne
recure to fynde of hym aduersite

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: The compleynt of feire Anelida And fals Arcite (f. 32)
msItem.title: Anelida and Arcite
msItem.incipit:
Thou fers god of Armes Mars the rede
that in the frosty contre called Trace…
msItem.explicit:
…and with her ovne honde she gan hit write
And sent to her theban knyght Arcite…
msItem.note: Ends incomplete after 30 stanzas, with note for continuance, ‘So thirled with the poynt & cetera’ in display script at end (f .35)

msItem.author: John Clanvowe (?)
msItem.title: The Book of Cupid, or The Cuckoo and the Nightingale
msItem.rubric: The Boke of Cupide god of Loue (f. 35v)
msItem.incipit:
The god of love a benedicite
How myghty and how grete a lorde is he…
msItem.explicit:
…Terme of lyve love hath withholde me
So lovde that with that songe I awoke

msItem.title: Truth
msItem.incipit:
ffle fro the pres and duelle with sothfastnesse
suffice the thy good thogh hit be smale…
msItem.explicit:
…Weyve thy lust and let thy goste the lede
and trouthe shal the delyuer hit is no drede

msItem.title: Lespistre de Cupide
msItem.rubric: Littera Cupidinis dei Amatoris directa subditis suis amatoribus (f. 40)
msItem.incipit:
Cupido vn to whos comaundement
the gentil kynrede of goddis an hy…
msItem.explicit:
…the yere of grace Ioyful and Iocunde
A thousand and foure hondred and secounde
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit littera Cupidinis dei amatoris directa suis subditis (f. 47)
msItem.note: hocclyffe (added by Stowe, f. 40); T. hocleve (added by Stowe, f. 47)

msItem.title: Ragmanys Rolle
msItem.incipit:
My ladyes and my maistresses echone
lyke hit vnto your humbyble wommanhede…
msItem.explicit:
…and in the rolle last as in wrytynge
I rede that this game ende in your hood

msItem.title: La Belle Dame sans Mercy
msItem.rubric: Balade de la bele Dame sanz mercy
msItem.incipit:
HAlffe in a dreme not fully wel awakyd
The golden slepe me wrapt vndir his wing…
msItem.explicit:
…And in their trouth purpose hem to endure
I pray god sende hem bettir aventure
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit la bele dame sanz mercy

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Temple of Glas
msItem.rubric: The temple of Bras [crossed out with ‘glas’ added over by Stowe, then ‘Glas’ added below by another hand imitating medieval style] (f. 63); The temple of Bras (RT); Explicit the temple of Bras (f. 82v)
msItem.incipit:
FOr thoght constreynt and grevous hevynesse
ffor pensyfhede and for high distresse…
msItem.explicit:
…I mene the benigne and goodly of hir face
now go thy way and put the in hir grace

msItem.title: Legend of Good Women
msItem.rubric: The prologe of ix goode Wymmen (f. 83)
msItem.incipit:
A thousande tymes I haue herd telle
ther ys Ioy in heuene and peyne in helle…
msItem.explicit:
…And til she was kaught and fetred in prison
This tale ys sayde for this conclusion

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Parlement of Foules
msItem.incipit:
THe lyf so short the crafte so longe to lerne
Thassay so harde so sharpe the conquerynge…
msItem.explicit:
…That I shal mete somme thyng for to fare
The bet and thus to rede I wol not spare
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit tractatus de congregacione volucrum die sancti Valentini (f. 129v)

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Book of the Duchesse
msItem.rubric: The booke of the Duchesse (f. 130) …made by Geffrey Chawcyer at þe request of þe duck of lancastar pitously complaynynge the deathe of þe sayd dutchesse blanche (added by John Stow, 16th century, f. 130); Explicit the boke of the duchesse (f. 147v)
msItem.incipit:
I Have grete wonder be this lyghte
How that I lyve for day ne nyght…
msItem.explicit:
…As I kan best and that anoon
This was my sweuene now hit ys doon

msItem.title: Balade with Envoy to Alison
msItem.incipit:
O lewde boke with thy foole rudenese
Sith thou hast neyther beaute ne eloquence…
msItem.explicit:
…Of grace I beseche alegge let your writynge
Now of al goode syth ye be best lyvynge
msItem.note: Copied as an envoy to fols. 130r–147v.

msItem.title: On the chaunse of the dyse
msItem.incipit:
FIrst myn vnkunnynge and my rudenesse
Vnto yow alle that lysten knowe here chaunce…
msItem.explicit:
…For hasarde hath with maystry quytte me soo
My while that I ioylesses now leue in woo

msItem.rubric: Balade vpon the Chaunse of the Dyse (f. 148)
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit Balade vpon the chaunse of the dyse (f. 148)
Explicit the Chaunce of thee Dyse (f. 154)

msItem.note: Balade (3 stanzas, f. 148) treated as separate work from Chaunces (56 stanzas, ff. 148-154).

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Hous of Fame
msItem.rubric: The house of ffame (f. 154v); Here endeth the booke of Fame (f. 183v)
msItem.incipit:
GOd turne vs euery dreme to goode
ffor hyt is wonder be the Roode…
msItem.explicit:
…Thus in dreaming and in game
Ended this litel booke of Fame
msItem.note: Last 12 lines and explicit added by hand of 17th century; original hand ends, But he semed for to be / A man of grete auctorite (f. 183v).

msItem.rubric: The x Commaundements of Love (f. 184); Explicit the x commandements of Love (f. 185v)
msItem.title: ‘The X Commaundments of love’
msItem.incipit:
Certes ferre extendeth yet my reason
This mater as yet should be to discryue…
msItem.explicit:
…For true seruice him to auance
And call him into your remembrance
msItem.note: Added by a hand of the 17th century.

msItem.title: Compleynt unto Pite
msItem.rubric: Balade (f. 187); complainte of the deathe of pitie (added by John Stow, f. 187)
msItem.incipit:
PIte that I haue sought so yore agoo
with hert soore and ful of besy peyne…
msItem.explicit:
…Thus for your deth I may wel wepe and pleyne
With herte sore and ful of besy peyne

msItem.title: ABC hymn to the Virgin
msItem.rubric: Chawcers A.b.c. (added by John Stow, f. 188v)
msItem.incipit:
ALmyghty and alle mercyable quene
To whom al this worlde fleeth for socour…
msItem.explicit:
…Brynge vs to that paleyce that ys bilte
To penytentys that been to mercye able

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: Balade de vilage saunz Peynture Par Chaucer (f. 191)
msItem.title: Balade of Fortune
msItem.incipit:
This wrechched worldes transmutacioun
As wele and woo now pouerte and now riche honoure…
msItem.explicit:
…Prayeth his beeste frend of his noblesse
That to some beter estate he may atteyne

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Lenvoy de Chaucer à Scogan
msItem.incipit:
To broken been the statuteȝ hye in hevene
That creat weren eternaly to dure…
msItem.explicit:
…Mynne thy frend there it may fructyfye
ffare wel and loke thow neuer eft love dyffye
msItem.note: Scribal marginal notes, ‘id est vii planetes’ beside third line of first stanza and ‘id est Wyndesor’ and ‘id est a Grenewich’ beside first and third lines of last stanza (f. 193)

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Complaynt to his Empty Purse
msItem.rubric: The complaynt of Chaucer to his Purse (f. 193)
msItem.incipit:
To yow my purse and to noon other wight
Complayn I for ye be my lady dere…
msItem.explicit:
…And ye that mowen alle myn harme amende
haue mynde vppon my supplicacioun

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: L’Envoy de Chaucer a Bukton
msItem.incipit:
My maister Bukton whan of Criste our kyng
Was axed what ys trouthe or sothefastnesse…
msItem.explicit:
…God graunte yow your lyfe frely to lede
In fredam for ful harde it is to be bonde

msItem.title: The Golden Mean
msItem.quote:
Better is to suffre and fortune abyde
And hastely to clymbe and sodeynly to slyde

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Lak of Stedfastnesse
msItem.incipit:
Some tyme the worlde was so stedfast and stable
That mannes worde was obligacioun…
msItem.explicit:
…Drede god do law loue trouthe and worthynesse
And wedde thy folke ayeyne to stedfastnesse

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer (attrib.)
msItem.title: Against Women Inconstant
msItem.incipit:
Madame that throgh your newfangelnesse
Many a seruaunt haue put out of your grace
msItem.explicit:
…Alle lyght for somer ye wote wel what I mene
In sted of bliw thus may ye were al grene

msItem.author: John Lydgate (attrib.)
msItem.title: Four things that make a man fall from reason
msItem.rubric: Quatuor infatuant honor etas femina vinum
msItem.quote:
Wurship wommen wyne vnweldy age
Maken men to foune for lakke of ther resoun
Elde causeth dulnesse and dotage
Worship causeth chaunge of condicioun
Excesse of wyne blyndeth discrecioun
And bookes alle that Poetes wroot and radde
Seyn women moste maken men to madde

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.incipit:
Deceyt disceyveth and shal be deceyved
ffor by deceyt who is deceyvable…
msItem.explicit:
…ffor whoo with fraude fraudelent ys founde
To a defrauder fraude wol ay rebounde

msItem.title: A single stanza rhyme royal, occurring separately and in combinations
msItem.incipit:
The worlde so wide thaire so remuable
The sely man so litel of stature…
msItem.explicit:
…That made is of these foure thus flyttyng
May stedfast be as here in his lyving

msItem.title: Tyed with a Line
msItem.incipit:
The more I goo the ferther I am behinde
The ferther behinde the ner my wayes ende…
msItem.explicit:
…Is thys ffortune not I or infortune
Though I go lowse tyed am I with a lune

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer (attrib.)
msItem.title: Two proverbial riddles with questions and answers
msItem.quote:
What shul these clothes thus many folde
loo this hoote somers day
After grete hete cometh colde
No man caste his pilch away
Of al this worlde the large compace
yt wil not in my Armes tweyne
Whoo so mochel wol embrace
litel therof he shal distreyne

msItem.title: ‘The complaynte ageyne Hope’
msItem.incipit:
As I stoode in studyinge alloone
Astonyed in studye wel colde…
msItem.explicit:
…Than I doo that I with eyen se
hope in hope out thus kan ye foles fede

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer (attrib.)
msItem.title: An Amorous Complaint (Compleint Damours)
msItem.incipit:
I whiche that am the sorwfullest man
That in this worlde was euer yet lyvinge…
msItem.explicit:
…And yet wol I euer more hir serue
And loue hir best al thogh she do me sterue

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve (?)
msItem.title: Virelai to Henry V for money
msItem.incipit:
Victoriouse kyng oure lorde moste graciouse
We humble legemen to youre highnesse…
msItem.explicit:
…lat nat the strook of Indigence vs mate
Excellent prince Mirour of prowesse

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Beware of Doublenesse
msItem.incipit:
This worlde is ful of variaunce
In euery thing whoo taketh hede…
msItem.explicit:
…Sette on youre brest your self tassure
A myghty shelde of doublenesse

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: Ab inimicis nostris defende nos criste (f. 199*v)
msItem.title: A Prayer for King Henry VI and his Queen and the People
msItem.incipit:
Most souereigne lord o blessed crist ihesu
ffrom oure enemyes delyuer vs and oure foon…
msItem.explicit:
…And ay preserve vnder thy myghty honde
hym and hys moder thy peple and thy londe
msItem.note: John lidgat (added in the sixteenth century after ‘Explicit’, f. 200v)
With a variant envoy of four stanzas with refrain: ‘And preserve vnder thy myghty honde / him and his moder thy peple and thy londe’.

msItem.title: Truth
msItem.incipit:
fflee fro the pres and dwelle with withfastnes
Suffise vn to thy good though hyt be smalle…
msItem.explicit:
…Weyve thy lust and let thy gooste the lede
And trouthe shall the delyuer hyt is no drede

msItem.author: John Lydgate (attrib.)
msItem.title: Reson and Sensuallyte
msItem.note: Freely translated from Les Echecs amoureux (lines 1–4873)
msItem.rubric: Reson and sensuallyte compylid by John lydgat (add by hand of 16th century, f. 202)
msItem.incipit:
TO alle folkys vertuouse
That gentil ben and amerouse…
msItem.explicit:
…Ther stood a povne of gret renoun
Callyd delectacioun…

msItem.title: ‘How a louer prayseth hys lady’
msItem.rubric: How A Louer prayseth hys Lady (f. 306)
msItem.incipit:
WHen the son the laumpe of heuen ful lyght
Phebus with hys eye ful gret round and bryght…
msItem.explicit:
…Let other amende hyt that better kunne
ffor kunnyng in me was neuer kunne
msItem.note: Last word, ‘kunne’, marked for expunction and ‘nene’ added after by a later hand of 16th century.

msItem.title: A parody of the mass (the ‘Venus Mass’ perhaps by Lydgate), a series of love lyrics in varying forms for Introibo, Confiteor, Misereatur, Officium, Kyrie, Gloria, and Oryson
msItem.incipit:
Wyth all myn hool herte entere
To fore the famous Riche Autere…
msItem.explicit:
…And make ther Ioye to Renewe
Swich as wyl neuer be chaungable
msItem.note: With headings for the various parts of the mass, e.g., Introito and later Confiteor on f. 314; continues with The Epystel in prose; on ff. 316v-317v.

msItem.title: A Balade
msItem.incipit:
TO fle the sett of alle mysgouernaunce
I am truly wyth hole in sych a palace…
msItem.explicit:
…Wherfor I must obbey her womanhede
Constreynd of hert wyth stedfast loue and drede

msItem.title: A Balade addressed to the beloved
msItem.incipit:
And os for yow that most ar in my mynde
Loke in what wyse the wyll I be demened…
msItem.explicit:
…But of my wo sumwhat I wold ye wyst
I can no more do wyth me what yow lyst

msItem.title: A Balade attributed to the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
O lord god what yt is gret plesaunce
ffor me to thynke so goodly and so fayr…
msItem.explicit:
…I know her not olyue that in thys case
Is bettir worthy ther to haue a place

msItem.title: A Compleynt against Fortune, possibly by the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
Now lyst fortune thus for me to purueye
That I ne may vn to your speche attayn…
msItem.explicit:
…Myn hert ys ther os yt wyl not remeue
And so I lyue almost out of byleue

msItem.title: A Compleynt, a testament bequeathing the lover’s heart and will
msItem.incipit:
Knelyng allon ryght thus I may make my wylle
As your seruaunt in euery maner wyse…
msItem.explicit:
…I can no more but alle my faythfull tryst
It lythe in yow demene me as ye lyst

msItem.title: A lover’s address to his mistress, possibly by the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
Ryght goodly flour to whom I owe seruyse
Wyth alle myn hert & to none othir wyght…
msItem.explicit:
…That lord a boue that syteth in his empire
He send yow ioy of alle that ye desyre

msItem.title: A Compleynt, possibly by the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
O wofull hert prisound in gret duresse
Which canst not playn nor opyn thy dysese…
msItem.explicit:
…And trysteth well that in ryght goodly wysse
She wyll reward the for thy seruysse

msItem.author: Charles d’Orléans
msItem.title: A Compleynt
msItem.incipit:
O thou ffortune whyche hast the gouernaunce
Of alle thynges kyndly mevyng to and fro…
msItem.explicit:
…ffor thys thou doost of very wylfulnesse
Why wyltow not wythstand myn heuuynesse

msItem.title: A Compleynt against daunger, possibly by the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
O cruell daunger all myn aduersarye
Of whom alle louers aught sore to complayne…
msItem.explicit:
…Vpon this to make apoyntement
That fro hens forth alle partyse may be plesyd

msItem.title: A Compleynt, possibly by the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
Now must I nede part out of your presence
Whiche causeth me to lyue in gret dystresse…
msItem.explicit:
…I wyl be truly hers in euery place
Besechyng her accept me to her grace

msItem.title: A Compleynt
msItem.incipit:
What shuld me cause or ony wyse to thynk
To haue plesaunce or Ioy in any kynde…
msItem.explicit:
…But I that am not worthy to be blamyd
Me thynke yt wrong thus for to be dyffamed

msItem.title: Compleynt
msItem.incipit:
Walkyng allone of wyt full desolat
In my sprytes turmentyd to and fro…
msItem.explicit:
…And syth I ment but treuth os in this case
haue routh on me and take me to thy grace

msItem.title: A Supplicacion
msItem.incipit:
Besechyth mekly in ryght lowly myse
Now in hys nede your suget and seruaunt…
msItem.explicit:
…Wherfore do now a charytable dede
To hys entent this lytill byll to spede

msItem.title: ‘A lettyr’, attributed to the Duke of Suffolk
msItem.incipit:
Myn hertys Ioy and all myn hole plesaunce
Whom that I serue and shall do faythfully…
msItem.explicit:
…Of verey trouth as thou canst wele remembre
At myn vpryst the fyst day of decembre

msItem.title: A Compleynt, the healing of the wounded lover—three stanzas rhyme royal
msItem.incipit:
The tyme so long the payn ay mor and more
That in what wyse It may be long enduryd…
msItem.explicit:
…Lat me not dye syth I so long haue serued
ffor god yt knowyth I neuer so deserued

msItem.title: A Compleynt of unfairness
msItem.incipit:
What schall I say to whom schall I compleyn
I wot not who wyll on my forus rewe…
msItem.explicit:
…But for to thynk how my sorous renewe
Thus to endure yt is a wondir thyng

msItem.incipit:
My best bylouyd lady and maistresse
To whom I must of verey ryght obey…
msItem.explicit:
…Wrytyn in hast of verrey trouth to say
At [blank space left] vpon our lady day

msItem.title: A Compleynt against unjust treatment
msItem.incipit:
Not far fro marche in the ende of feueryere
Allon I went vpon myn awn dysport…
msItem.explicit:
…That trouth shall reynge and the gouernaunce
And hertys trew to lyue in thair plesaunce

msItem.title: ‘How þe louer is sett to serve þe floure’, including a reproof to Lydgate
msItem.incipit:
Myn hert ys set and all myn hole entent
To serue this flour in my most humble wyse…
msItem.explicit:
…ffor alle that euer thou hast sayde byfore
Haue mynde of this for now I wryte no more

msItem.title: ‘The Parliament off Cupyde gode of love’
msItem.incipit:
O ye louers which in gret heuynes
Haue led your lyfe by many a straunge way…
msItem.explicit:
…Off your maters sych tydynges yow to sende
That fro hens forth we take non hevynesse

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: The regnynge of kynges After the conquest by the Monke of Bury (f. 330v)
msItem.title: Verses on the Kings of England
msItem.incipit:
The myghty William duke of Normandye
As bokes olde maken mencyoun…
msItem.explicit:
…Of vertuouse lyf & chose hym for his knyght
Longe to reioyce & regne here in his right
msItem.note: Added to MS by a contemporary hand; after last line, concludes, Summa annorum a tempore Willelmi ducis normanorum vsque ad tempus henrici sexti CCC xxvᵗⁱ (fol. 332v).

decoDesc.decoNote: Fine miniature, border, initial. By William Abell. Fine drawing (retouched) of 16th century, end, fol. 9. (Pächt and Alexander iii. 974, pl. XCI)

recordHist.source: Summary description by Elizabeth Solopova and Matthew Holford, based on the Summary Catalogue and supplementary sources. Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 2, p. 778 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 2, p. 779 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 2, p. 780

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised with consultation of original.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
